title: Trump considers delisting Chinese firms - sources
text:
President Donald Trump's administration is considering delisting Chinese companies from U.S. stock exchange in what would mark a dramatic escalation in trade tensions.

That's according to sources, two of whom said the move would be part of a broader effort to limit U.S. investment in Chinese companies.

The discussions within the White House are occurring ahead of planned trade talks in October following months of tit for tat moves in a trade war that has hit global growth and sparked rollercoaster swings in markets.

While the idea of delisting could be tactical ahead of those talks, according to one source, the main goal would be to counteract the civilian-military fusion of Chinese technology firms, the Made in China 2025 industrial development program targeting key industries for domination and a growing surveillance state in Xinjiang.

The source said there are longstanding concerns about U.S. capital enabling those activities, especially as the lines blur between state-owned and private companies in China.

As of February, 156 Chinese companies were listed on the NASDAQ and New York Stock Exchanges, including at least 11 state-owned firms.
